text: It's a very good question. It gets me scared sometimes because you can go so many different directions. And at the end of the day, you still have to make yourself relevant to your clients. So even though you have the freedom of choices in a way, you're still linked to basically staying relevant to your client base and I think that's what's guiding in very loose terms, what is guiding my research agenda. It's how do I stay relevant to my own clients? What are the topics that will still be discussed in a year, two years, three years times? And in a way, because we're, I'm lucky enough to discuss with a lot of people. So whenever you have a new trend emerging, you sort of, if you're careful enough and if you know how to listen enough, you can catch that. And I guess it's how all that research on risk-primer investing got started. In 2012 is when some sales guy and some came to see me and they said, oh, you know, in the equity world at the time I was like fixed income quants. I was very much interested into swap options, related strategies, using interest rates, derivatives, very much into trying to measure correlations in financial markets. So nothing to do with factor investing on risk-primer. And one guy came in and they say, oh, but you know, lots of people are talking about factor investing in equities. And risk-primer investing in equities. And from my fixed income background, I said, yeah, yeah, risk-primer, it's scary. Right? It's like you're selling a 10 year bonds and you're getting some duration premium in for that risk-primer. I said, no, no, no, it's not that. It's about trend flowing, quality investing. And then I started to dig up. And well, I guess seven years down the line, that topic is still relevant. So at the time we had to make a decision to start to research about that. And I guess. That's how I tried to gear my research agenda. So back in 2010, we had some colleagues coming back. They went to do some studies in that Stanford and they studied with Hasty and Tipshirani, the guys who authored the elements of statistical learnings, which to me is like the very first book you need to read if you want to do machine learning. And back in 2010, no one in finance would talk about machine learning. It was just a concept. And we said, oh, this is a concept. So this is the elements of statistical learning is exactly what we're trying to do. We're trying to learn statistically from financial markets. So let's try to apply all those techniques there. We started to develop a lot of models using their books in the business cases that we were facing. And I guess that's how little by little we stayed relevant because that topic becomes so much, so much popular.
